div.head: THE UPPER NILE SETTLEMENT.
div.p: Something in the nature of a historical retrospect is necessary in order to appreciate the significance of the settlement which has been arrived at between Great Britain and the Congo Free State with respect to certain disputed territory on the Upper Nile. To understand the causes which have led to the friction between the two Powers it is necessary to go back to 1885, when the Egyptian Government evacuated the Sudan. The precise status of the territory south of Wady Haifa during the period of Muhdist list dominion gave rise to international questions of considerable nicety. Was the suzerainty if the Sultan of Turkey over the Upper Nile basin to be regarded as continuing in spite of the interruption of effective occupation ? Or was the abandoned territory to revert to the condition of “no man’s land” where finding and conquering was keeping 1 The a swers given to these questions were at once inconclusive and conflicting, says the "Morning Post”.

In the early Nineties the following was roughly the situation. By the Anglo-German Agreement of 1890 Great Britain acquired as her sphere of influence territories which, in addition to certain districts bordering upon Victoria Nyanza and Lake Albert, virtually included the old Egyptian Equatorial Province. At that time, however, the effective occupation of this territory was out of the question, and the area under direct British control was practically limited to Uganda. Meanwhile other Powers were displaying an unmistakable interest in the valley of the Upper Nile. The forces of the Congo Free State had penetrated to the banks of the river, although the expedition had been forced to retire without securing a permanent footing. It was also becoming increasingly evident that France entertained designs in the same direction. Having declined to recognise the Anglo-German Agreement of 1890, she apparently regarded herself as being at liberty to take possession of any part of the territories concerned which had not been actually occupied. Under these circumstances the position of the Liberal Government was extremely difficult. While reluctant to abandon England’s claim to the control of the Upper Nile, they had to reckon with the fact that the temper of the party would be resolutely
opposed to any expenditure of blood or money for the purpose of adding to British territory and British responsibilities. Placed in this dilemma the Cabinet had recourse to a device which at least possessed the merit of ingenuity Their solution of the difficulty lay in the employment of the Congo State as a means of counteracting the ambitions of France. Accordingly under the Anglo-Congolese Agreement of May, 1894, Great Britain leased to King Leopold, a considerable tract of country bounded on the east by the Nile from Lake Albert to Fashoda, on the north by the 10th parallel of North latitude, and on the west by the 25th meridian of East longitude, and on the south by the Congo Nile watershed. A glanoe at the map shows that the area thus described includes the whole of the district known as the Bahr-el-Ghazil. The terms of lease were as follows : The portion of the leas ed territory lying to the W. of the 80th meridian of E. longitude was to be held so long as tie Congo State should remain, as an independent State or a Belgian Colony, under King Leopold and his successors. On the other hand, the lease of the portion lying to the east of the same meridian was to expire on King Leopold’s death. The other provisions of the agreement, which were subsequently cancelled, need not here be noticed. The effect of this arrangement was obvious. In the first place Great Britain secured from the Congo State the recognition of her sphere of influence as determined by the Anglo-German Agreement of 1890; secondly, and most important, she interposed an apparenetly insuperable obstacle between the French sphere and the Nile, inasmuch as the country to the north of the 10th parallel was effectively barred by the Mahdists.

France, as might be expected, was not disposed to take this reverse lying down. Moreover, an effective means of asserting hen elf was opportunely to hand. She was at the moment engaged in negotiations with King Leopold with reference to the frontier between the French and Belgian possessions in the Congo Basin. In order, therefore, to obtain a satisfactory settlement of the boundary question the King of the Belgians was compelled in August, 1894, to enter into an agreement with France by which he renounced all right of occupation or influence in that part of the leased territory which lay west and north 5 deg. 30 min. North latitude and the 30th parallel of E. longitude. In other words, he practically assigned to France the lease of all the territory comprised in the Anglo Congolese Agreement with the exception of the Lado enclave.

The next chapter in the story deals with those relations between France and Great Britain which are centred in the Fashoda affair. In regard to these events, which are still fresh in the minds of most people, it is only necessary to point oat that the claims put forward by France on the strength of her agreement with the Congo Fres State were finally renounced in virtue of the Anglo-French Agreement of March, 1899, by which she recognised inter alia the paramount tights in the Upper Nile Valley acquired by the victors at Omdurman. France having thus retired, the relations between the Congo Free State on the one baud and Great Britain and the Sudan on the other still remained to be cleared up.

If the rights in the territories (outside the Lado enclave), which hid been leased to King Leopold under the Anglo-Congolese Agreement of May, 1894, had been assigned to France in August of the same year, it might fairly be argued that under the Anglo-French Agreement of 1899 the same rights had been reassigned to Great Britain. In that case the title of the latter as leaseholder would have been merged in her position as freeholder. If that contention has not been put forward by the British Government, it may be that they considered themselves to be estopped by a passage in a despatch written in August, 1898, by the late Lord Salisbury to the British Ambassador in Paris, in which, referring to the Franco-Congolese Agreement of August, 1891, he remarks that “that concession on his [t e, King Leopold’s] part did not diminish the significance of the act as an assertion of her rights by England.” In view of his sentence it may no doubt have been held that the British Government was bound to regard the original lease as still continuing in fall force.

Be that as it may, it is highly satisfactory to learn that* the new arrangement between Great Britain and the Congo State has given effect to a settlement which in logic, if not in right. Great Britain had every reason to demand. The point of the agreement, signed, last week by Sir Edward Grey and Baron van Eetvelde, consists, it would seem, in the cancellation of the 1894 lease, not merely in respect of that part of the Bahr-el-Ghszal situated to the west of the 30th meridian of East longitude, but of the whole of the leased area outside the Lado enclave. The last-named district will presumably continue to be held on lease by King Leopold until his death, after which it will automatically to Great Britain.

div.head: Cairo Bourse.
div.p: The Committee of Bankers will meet on Monday at the Credit Foncier offices to deliberate upon the Cairo Bourse question.

div.head: Suez Canal Company.
div.p: The Board of the Suez Canal have ratified unanimously the appointment of M. de Gorostarzu to be Chef do Contentieux of the company at Paris.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal into Egypt from January 1 to May 17 amounted to 491,954 tons, as compared with 312,082 tons during the same period last year.

div.head: Le Quartorze Juillet.
div.p: A meeting of the French colony at Cairo will be held at the Cercle Francis on Tuesday afternoon at 5.30, to arrange for the celebration of the 14th July.

div.head: An Assouan Case.
div.p: The Italian Court at Cairo has condemnea Michele Conte to 25 days’ imprisonment and t fine of 83 francs for defrauding workmen and contractors at Assouan.

div.head: Rudolph Home.
div.p: Mme and Mlle Campos and Mme Vita Israel have made a large collection of clothing for the poor refugee Jews who are under the care of the committee of the Rudolph Home.

div.head: St. George's Church.
div.p: The services at the garrison church, Mustapha, to-morrow will be as follows :—Holy Communion, 7.30 a.m. ; first parade service, 10.15 a m. ; second parade service, 11.15 a.m. ; evening service, 6.30 p.m.

div.head: Alhambra.
div.p: The two last performances of the variety company at the Alhambra will take place to-morrow, in the afternoon and evening. The theatre will be dosed on Monday in preparation for the opening on Tuesday by the Italian operetta company with The Geisha.

div.head: The "Epargne Immobiliers" Co.
div.p: A contemporary remarks : .‘II en a approuvé taut d’autres qu’on ee demande ce que ceux-ci pouvaieut bien être.”

div.head: Female Diplomacy.
div.p: We extract the following from the "Progrès,” which has certainly introduce! a new factor into diplomacy, namely, la femme diplomate :— S. M. le Sultan a conféré le grand cordon de l’ordre du Chefakat à. Mme Gryparis, femme diplomate bien connue qui représente la Grèce à Constantinople.”

div.head: French Consular Court.
div.p: The manager of the Gonnet-Levy theatrical company was charged at the French Consular Court in Cairo yesterday with having produced a play at the Ambassadeurs which brought ridicule on the President of the French Republic. After a rather lengthy hearing, the accused was fined 1,000 francs.

div.head: Another New Company.
div.p: The Council of Ministers, at its next meeting, which will probably be on Thursday, will have submitted to it for approval the statutes of the new limited liability company "The Nile Transport,” which, with a share capital of L. E. 100,000, will undertake exclusively the transport of goods by the river.

div.head: Syrians at San Francisco.
div.p: Some Arabic newspapers published in New York report that more than two hundred Syrian families were involved in the recent disaster at San Francisco, bat there was only one casualty. The Syrian emigrants in the other American States have opened subscriptions in aid of their brethren at San Francisco.

div.head: Freemasonry.
div.p: At the regular meeting of the Ragheb Lodge No 51 to be held at the Masonic Hall, Boulac-road, Cairo, on Monday evening, 21st inst., at 8.30 an argent case for Masonic charity will be laid before the members. It is hoped there will be a good attendance. All members of other lodges are cordially invited to be present.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: F.R.I.B.A., will deliver a lecture next Saturday, under the auspices of the Alexandria Literary Musical and Dramatic Society, on "Architecture, Ancient and Modern.” The lecture will be illustrated by an interesting series-of lantern views, some of which have been specially prepared for this lecture.

div.head: A Bedouin Fight.
div.p: Our Damanhour Correspondent reports that a fight has taken place between two tribes of Bedouins in that neighbourhood. Several men were wounded, and some are in a precarious condition. The cause is attributed to a love affair, the sons of both the chiefs of the tribes wishing to marry the same woman. Both these gallant young men are now in Damanhour Hospital, whence in all probability they will not come out alive again.

div.head: Calf Love Leads to Suicide.
div.p: Yesterday we announced that a Greek boy, thirteen years of age, had hilled himself by taking poison, and that his body had been found near Al Mezarita. The story of the circumstances that led to his suicide is a curious one, He was a pupil at the Averoff School at Alexandria and fell in love with a little Greek girl in the same school, twelve years of age. One day he wrote a love letter to her and entrusted the missive to a girl school friend of his sweetheart, who very properly at once gave it to her teacher. The result was that he was brought up and punished and his father communicated with. The parent in his turn reprimanded the youthful Romeo, who was so filled with remorse that he straightway put an end to his existence.

div.head: TORPEDO-BOAT DISASTER.
BOAT CAPSIZED OFF DAMIETTA.
div.p: The news of the capsizing of a torpedo-boat of the Mediterranean Fleet is, unhappily, confirmed. The information which is at present available is as follows : Torpedo-boats Nos. 63, 46, 83, 47 and the Noby with No. 56, left Port Said lest night, in the wake of H.M.S. Arrogant, Amethyst, and Thetis, bound in the direction of Malta. There was a heavy sea on at the time, and while the flotilla was off Damietta at about 3 o’clock this morning torpedo-boat No. 56, which was being towed by H.M.S. Arrogant, fouled the tow rope in the storm, and capsized in thirty fathoms of water. Of the crew of fifteen, seven were drowned, three of the others being severely injured. The torpedo boat was in command of Lieut. Addison, who is among the rescued.
News of the disaster was conveyed to Port Said by a wireless message from H.M.S. Amethyst to H.M.S. Minerva.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Major-General Bullock, C.B., G.O.C. in Egypt, and Major G. C. Knight, D A Q M.G., came down to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday.
Col. J. Magill, P.M.O. in Egypt, and Lieut.-Col. Martell, C.R.E. in Egypt, also came down to Alexandria yesterday.
Capt. G. Harding, A.S.C., has obtained three months’ leave of absence on private affairs, with permission to travel in Norway.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Captain W. H King, 6‘h Dragoons, has joined the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi and been posted to the Bahr-el-Ghazal province. Lieut. E. F. Stephenson, D.S.O., Gloucestershire Regiment, has also joined the Army with the rank of Bimbashi and been posted to the Khartoum district.

div.head: GHAZI MUKHTAR PACHA.
div.p: The “Spectator” thinks that, in view of recent developments in our position in Egypt, it is ridiculous that the Sultan should maintain a Turkish High Commissioner in Cairo. While the Imperial Commissioner, Mukhtar Pasha, confined himself to the dignified indolence of a great Turkish official, little harm was done, and we rightly tolerated him as a picturesque anachronism. As long as such anachronisms are not harmful, Englishmen of all kinds obey a very proper instinct in not only leaving them alone, but actually admiring them. When, however, anachronisms become dangerous they mast be removed, and it appears to us that the Turkish High Commissioner has now entered upon this stage,

"La Reforme," in its issue of yesterday, says:–
Au sujet du glorieux soldat certains journaux semblent faire un grief au représentant de la Turquie d'avoir exécuté les ordres qui'l recevait, et, par conséquent , d'avoir fait son devoir. Moukhtar pacha est Turc et il a défendu les prétensions de son sonverain avec l'éngergie et la franchise d'un soldat. Personne ne saurait donc lui en faire un grief.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES CASE.
div.p: The following is the text of |the ordinance of the Chambre de Conseil of the Cairo Mixed Courts in the case of the Ministre Public v. Messrs. Barois and Arbib and the Hon. A. J. Davey, late directors of the Sucreries Company :—

Omissis:
"Attendu que si parmi les actions punissables, il y en a qui existent par le seul fait de la perpétration ou de l'omission indépendamment de l'intention et ne sont que des contraventions, que les autres prennet leur criminalité dans l'intention, que l'instruction n'a prévenus de dol ou frande, que leur négligence ou leur imprudence d'avoir acquiescé à une distribution de dividendes fictifs sur la foi d'un bilan qu'ils n'ont pas vérifié, par une confiance trop grande dans la bonne foi des co-administrateurs, ne consititute qu'un quasi délit qui ne pourrait être poursuivi devant les tribunaux répressifs en l'absence de dol ou de fraude personnelle."
' Par ces motifs, oui le rapport conforme de M. le juge d'instruction, disons n'y avoir lieu à poursuite contre M.M. Davey, Barois et Arbib."

div.head: GAMBLING RAIDERS OUTWITTED.
div.p: Owing to the frequent raids which are made on the Cairo gambling hells by the police, accompanied by a Janissary of the Greek Consulate, some of the keepers of these establishments, finding themselves paralysed and losing money, have invented a fresh trick so as to nullify the police efforts ; they have set aside, in that part of the house inhabited by their families, a second room to which they and their clients retire and gamble. When the arrival of the police is notified, they absolutely refuse to they any summons to open the doors of communication, and the Janissaries of the Greek Consulate refuse to aid in this matter, saying that they are private apartments, and they cannot do. so without orders from their chiefs.

div.head: BOUNDARY PILLARS INCIDENT.
PUNISHMENT OF REPONSIBLE OFFICER.
div.p: The punishment of the officer commanding the Turkish troops who was responsible for the removal of the Egyptian boundary pillars at El Rafali constitutes the final act, and the complete admission of our rights in the Tabah dispute.

div.head: BAHR-EL-GHAZAL OPERATIONS.
OFFICERS REWARDED.
div.p: It is officially stated that Brevet-Captains Sutherland and Flint have been promoted to Majors as a reward for their services in the Bahr el Ghazal operations in 1905. Had Major Boulnois still lived he would have been recommended to the King for a reward.

div.head: HEAVY SEA AT SUEZ.
div.p: A southerly gale has been blowing at Suez since last night, and has rendered communication with the steamers lying in the roads very difficult.
H.M.S. Fox, which intended to enter the North Basin for coaling purposes, was unable to do so to-day, owing to the heavy seas.

div.head: SINAI BOUNDARY COMMISSION.
div.p: The members of the boundary commission are leaving Cairo for the frontier in a few days.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL LIBRARY.
div.p: The natives of Cairo are beginning to take far more interest in the Library, and to utilize it more extensively, than heretofore. In 1904, only 3,331 persons need the reading-rooms ; in 1905, they were need by 13,778 persons, or an average of about 40 readers a day. Of these, 13.000 were Egyptians. During the pilgrim season, the Library is visited by numbers of Moslems from Morocco, Algeria, Tunis, Turkey, and Russia. The number of persons who borrowed books for home use during the year was 52, of whom 37 were Europeans ; 1,275 volumes were lent out for home study in 1905, as compared to 926 in 1901. The exhibition rooms were closed for a month and a-half for structural alterations. Nevertheless, the number of visitors increased from 2,000 in 1904 to 8 132 in 1905. Of these latter, 2,375 were Europeans, and the remainder Egyptians.

div.head: GERMAN OFFICERS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The S.S. Neckar, from Tientsin, landed at Suez on Thursday 89 German officers of the East Asia Brigade. A special train conveyed Colonel von Ompteda and his staff to Cairo for the excursion to the Pyramids, etc. They put np at the Grand Continental Hotel and returned to Port Said yesterday by special train to join the Neckar. Colonel von Ompteda greatly appreciated the kindness of the Railway Administration, who kindly placed a saloon carriage at his disposal. The arrangements for the visit were carried out by the Hamburg-American Line.

div.head: THE "SOCIETE COMMERCIALIALE" ROBBERY.
div.p: Mr. Lumberopoulo, the cashier of the Societe Commerciale d'Egypte, who was recently sentenced to one year’s hard labour by the Attarin Court for robbing his firm of £2,200, which he had gambled away on the Bourse, has appealed against the sentence and has been sentenced to only six months’ imprisonment. The Court considered that his age and hitherto exemplary character justified a reduction of the sentence by half.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince, from Alexandria, arrived at Manchester on Friday.
The S.S. Cyprian Prince left Manchester on Friday with passengers and general cargo, and is due at Alexandria, viâ Tanis and Malta, on or about June 3.
The S. S. Ocean Prince, from Manchester with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterday,and is due at Alexandria on Tuesday next.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
COLLISSION IN THE CANAL.
div.p: Last Saturday the Titania reached Port Said in a damaged condition, having been run into by the S.S. Cromwell in the Canal at kilometre 127. The latter ship was able, in spite of the severe damage to her hull, to proceed to Suez New plates are being placed in tho Titania, and she will probably be able to proceed to Hull early next week.

div.head: Port Said and the Crisis.
div.p: On Sunday Port Said assumed a lively aspect, crowds being in all the main thoroughfares listening to the different bands. Although few, if any, ever contemplated any other answer to the Ultimatum, yet one could not help noting an under current of excitement. Though probably everyone remarked “just what I told you,” there was no doubt a feeling that the attitude.of Turkey was one which might have caused great unrest among the native populace, more especially in the interior. With three warships in the harbour and others within a day or two’s sail, there was no cause for anxiety here. It was noticed, however, that double guards were placed at the gates to the wharves, and that the police were in greater evidence than usual.

div.head: More Russian Troops.
div.p: Another 10,000 Russian troops passed through this week, on the S.S. Lonsdale, Slavoina, Monarch, Afghan Prince and Rippingham Grange. The Monarch had on board nearly 3,500 troops—this overcrowding her resulting, it was said, in the men having to lie down in batches.

div.head: Navy Movements.
div.p: On Sunday evening H.M.'s first-class cruiser Cornwall, commanded by Capt. Lyon, came to Port Said, and after provisioning and coaling, left next morning for Cyprus. The Hecla, the Amethyst, and the Arrogant arrived on follow, ing days, together with six torpedo boats, Nos. 56, 63, 46, 83, 47, and Noby, so that we have quite-a little fleet in the harbour under the command of Admiral Lambton on the flag-ship Minerva. The Hecla left on Tuesday evening for Malta, after discharging her cargo of ammunition.

div.head: Portuguese Troops.
div.p: On Wednesday the Angola came in with Portuguese troops from Lisbon, destined for Lorenzo Marquez. Probably Portugal is strengthening her forces there, to be prepared for the native unrest in Natal and German, East Africa spreading to the possessions of which Delagoa Bay is the port and capital.

div.head: A Maharajah's Visit.
div.p: The steamer Coromandel, an old P. & 0. liner, arrived on Tuesday, specially chartered by the Rajah of Hampora, who is accompanied by his hareem. His intended visit to Jaffa is in connection with his religion.

div.head: HEALTH IN THE SUDAN.
A FAVOURABLE REPORT.
div.p: Dr. Christophen, head of the Civil Medical Department, Sudan Government, in his annual report, say : —

The Sudan is not the fever stricken, smallpox ravaged country, into which the Egyptian diseases (Ophthalmie, Bilharzia, and Anchylostoma) are rapidly being introduced, while sleeping sickness is advancing, cholera and plague threatening Port Sudan, and leprosy creeping in from the west What are the facts! There, are five provinces at least which are practically free from the malaria infection— fever cannot originate there—namely, Haifa, Dongola, Berber, Khartoum, and Suakin; and, with the introduction of suitable dwellings and energetic mosquito brigades, other provinces will be freed from malaria. Small-pox shows itself occasionally, bat if the country can be vaccinated throughout, small-pox will disappear. Great advances have been made towards this end daring the last year or two. The carrier of sleeping-sickness has been caught in Sudan territory it is true, but so far not a single case of sleeping-sickness has been imported. Quarantine regulations have been instituted for Port Sudan and for the Sudan generally ; and the arrangements at Haifa have been so far successfal that plague and cholera have been kept out. Egyptian Ophthalmia is decidedly uncommon, and Bilharzia and Anchylostoma, the two principal Egyptian diseases, have not taken hold of the natives to any extent Lastly, the natives are amenable to medical treatment, so that there is little difficulty in carrying out measures for the security of the country against epidemics, so far as active opposition from the people is concerned. The Bahr el Ghazal must be excepted from this general statement,on account of our present want of knowledge of the character of its peoples, and that of the people of the Eastern Sudan, who are also still timid and suspicious. It is satisfactory to know that the natives of the country are gradually, gaining confidence in the hospitals. A native correspondent recently wrote to the “Sudan Times” in the following terms : —

"A few years back, the arrival of a medical officer in a village meant a general alarm ; everybody sought a hiding-place. Now, things have changed in such a manner that native patients flock to the hospital to be treated”

div.head: SUDAN AND CONGO.
THE ANGLO-CONGOLESE AGREEMENT.
div.p: The following is the full text of the Anglo-Congolese agreement recently concluded :–

Agreement between His Majesty Edward VII., King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and of the British Dominions beyond the Seas, Emperor of India, and His Majesty King Leopold II., Sovereign of the Independent State of the Congo, modifying the Agreement signed at Brussels on the 12th May, 1894.

The Undersigned, the Right Honourable Sir Edward Grey, a Baronet of the United Kingdom, a Member of Parliament, His Britannic Majesty’s Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, on behalf of His Britannic Majesty; and Baron van Eetvelde, Commander of the Order of Leopold, a Minister of State of the Independent State of the Congo, on behalf of His Majesty King Leopold II., Sovereign of the Independent State of the Congo, duly authorized thereto by their respective Sovereigns, have agreed as follows: —

div.head: Article I.
div.p: The lease of the territories granted by Great Britain to His Majesty King Leopold II., Sovereign of the Independent State of the Congo, by Article 2 of the Agreement signed at Brussels on the l.th May, 1894, is hereby annulled. No claims shall be put forward by either Party in connection with this lease,,or with any right derived therefrom. His Majesty King Leopold shall, however, continue daring his reign to occupy, on the same conditions as at present, the territory now held by him and known as the Lado Enclave. Within six months of the termination of His Majesty’s occupation the Enclave shall.be handed over to the Soudanese Government. Officials shall be appointed by the Soudanese and Congo State Governments to assess the value of such houses, stores, and other material improvements as may, by common agreement, be banded over with the Enclave, the amount agreed upon being paid to the Congo State by the Soudanese Government. The Enclave comprises the territory bounded by a line drawn from a point situated on the west shore of Lake Albert, immediately to the south of Mahagi, to the nearest point of the watershed between the Nile and Congo basins; thence the boundary follows that watershed op to its intersection from the north with the 30th meridian east of Greenwich, and that meridian up to its intersection with the parallel 5° 30’ of north latitude, whence it runs along that parallel to the Nile ; thence it follows the Nile southward to Lake Albert and the western shore of Lake Albert down to the point above indicated sooth of Mahagi.

div.head: Article II.
div.p: The boundary between the Independent State of the Congo on the one hand and the Anglo-Egyptian Soudan on the other, starting from the point of intersection from the south of the meridian of 30° longitude east of Greenwich with the watershed between the Nile and the Congo, shall follow the line of that watershed in a general north-westerly direction until it reaches the frontier between the Independent State of the Congo and French Congo.

Nevertheless, the strip of territory 25 kilm. in breadth stretching from the watershed between the Nile and the Congo up to the western shore of Lake Albert and including the port of Mahagi, of which a lease was granted to the Independent State of the Congo by Article 2 of the Agreement of the 12th May, 1894, shall continue in the possession of that State on the conditions laid down in that Article.

div.head: Article III.
div.p: The Government of the Independent State of the Congo undertake not to construct, or allow to be constructed, any work on or near the Semliki or Isango River, which would diminish the volume of water entering Lake Albert, except in agreement with the Sudanese Government.

div.head: Article IV.
div.p: A Concession shall be given, in terms to be agreed upon between the Sudanese and Congo State Governments, to an Anglo-Belgian Company for the construction and working of a railway from the frontier of the Independent State of the Congo to the navigable channel of the Nile, near Lade, it being understood that, when His Majesty’s occupation of the Enclave determines, this railway shall be wholly subject to the jurisdiction of the Sudanese Government. The actual direction of the line will be determined jointly by the Sudanese and Congo Governments.

In order to provide the capital expenditure required for the construction of this railway, the Egyptian Government undertake the guarantee a rate of interest of 3 per cent. on a sum which is not to exceed £800,000.

div.head: Article V.
div.p: A port open to general commerce, with suitable provision tor the storing and transhipment of merchandize, shall be established at the terminus of the railway. When His Majesty’s occupation of the Enclave determines, a Congolese or Belgian Company shall be permitted to possess a commercial depôt and quays on the Nile at this port. Such depôt and quays shall, however, in no case lead to the acquisition of extra territorial rights, and all individuals in, or connected with, them in the Sudan, shall be wholly subject to Soudanese Laws and Regulations.

div.head: Article VI.
div.p: Trading vessels flying the Congolese or Belgian flag shall have 'hi right of navigating and trading on the waters of the Upper Nile, no distinction as regards trading facilities being made between them and British or Egyptian trading vessels, but such vessels shall in no case acquire extra territorial rights, and shall be wholly subject to Soudanese Laws and Regulations.

div.head: Article VII.
div.p: Persons and merchandize passing through Soudanese or Egyptian territory from the Congo State, or going to it, will, for purposes of transit or transport on the Nile, or on the Soudanese or Egyptian railway systems, be treated similarly to Egyptian or British persons and merchandize coming from or going to British Possessions.

div.head: ARTICLE VIII.
div.p: All disputes which may occur hereafter in connection with the limits of the frontiers of the Independent State of the Congo, including the boundary laid down in the first paragraph of Article II. of the present Agreement, shall, in the event of the Parties rot being able to come to an amicable understanding, be submitted to the Arbitration of The Hague Tribunal, whose decision shall be binding on both Parties, it being, however, understood that this clause can, in no way whatever, be applied to any questions regarding the lease mentioned in Article 2 of the Agreement signed at Brussels on the 12th May, 1894, and in Article I of the present Agreement.

Sir Edward Grey, to whom the credit is due. for a satisfactory settlement of the dispute with Turkey, is of youthful appearance, which is, to a certain extent, the result of his activity as an athlete. He is probably the finest tennis player in the House, and won the M.C.C. prize for his skill in this respect in 1896. His favourite pastime, however, is fishing, and he has also written extensively on his experiences as an angler. When Mr. Gladstone was told that he preferred fishing to politics he exclaimed with horror : “The idea of a man sacrificing his chances of a great career for such a dull pursuit as this dry fly fishing !"

div.head: WHO IS A BEDOUIN?
div.p: The Government want a satisfactory definition of a Bedouin for the following reason. Ever since the days of Mehemet Ali, the Bedouins have been exempted from the obligation of military service. For many reasons it would be extremely undesirable to take away From them their privilege in this respect, which they prize very highly. A practical difficulty, however, has arisen in deciding who is and who is not a Bedouin. A census of the Bedouinss was made more than half a century ago, but it was originally very imperfect, and is now of little use, because large numbers of Bedouins and their families have come into Egypt since it was made. Moreover, some of the records of this census appear to have been destroyed. Under these circumstances, it was decided, after some lengthy discussions, to accept the certificates of the Omdehs and Sheikhs on the subject of Bedouin origin. There is, however, now reason to suppose that some of these Omdehs and Sheikhs are Riving certificates to persons who have no right to receive them, and, in fact, are making a somewhat lucrative trade by the delivery of certificates. The natter, wbich is one of some difficulty, is now under consideration.

div.head: COMMONS AND LORDS.
LABOURITES INDIGNANT.
div.p: The House of Lords rejected the Labour Bill, prohibiting aliens from entering Great Britain to replace strikers, which the Commons passed without discussing. The Labourites are most indignant, and raised the question in the House of Commons asking how long would a House, totally irresponsible to the country, be tolerated.

div.head: THE NAVY.
THE SQUADRONS TO BE ABOLISHED.
div.p: The “Daily Telegraph” understands that the Cape and West African squadrons will be abolished and the few ships remaining placed under the East Indies command.

div.head: 49,000 TEETOTAL SOLDIERS.
DUKE OF CONNAUGHTS VIEWS ON TEMPERANCE.
div.p: The Duke of Connaught, presiding at the annual meeting of the Army Temperance Association at the Royal United Service Institution last week, said that the War Office recognised the value of the association in improving the work and the morals of the British soldier, and in fitting him for civilian life on leaving the Army. There could be no question as to the superiority of the temperate over the intemperate man. During his tours of inspection he always inquired about ,the temperance of the Army, and was gratified to hear very often the remark, "We don’t drink much here ; we re all right” (hear, hear). This was not good for the canteen, but, then, the canteen did not exist for drinking only, but to enable the men to mess well and cheaply. There were now 49,000 total abstainers in the Army, and when they thought of the small beginnings of the Army Temperance Association they would see that great progress had been made (cheers).

Lord Methuen, who supported the Duke, said that he thought the total abstainers were inclined to put their case a little too strongly. If they did that, instead of encouraging temperance they ran the risk of driving the soldier from the canteen to bad company and bad beer outside. He had tried total abstinence for three months, and found it good for the eyes.
